subtitle: In this video, I'd like to take a look at
the two most well-known pieces of art in
the world. These are the most visited and
the most written about pieces of art in
the world. That's Leonardo da Vinci's
Mona Lisa and Michelangelo's Creation of
Adam fresco.
Let's just take a look at this in Q.
I'm going to open up the library browser
and bring in the golden rectangle that I
just made in an earlier video and what
I'd like to do is reorient this to the
portrait orientation for it to analyze
the Mona Lisa. So I'm going to select
that and rotate it ninety degrees in the
counterclockwise direction, that's a
positive number; I'll delete the
original. There it is.
And then I'm going to move this with
translate. I'm going to pick it up from
the midpoint there and I'm going to zoom
in here on the painting and place this
down on the lower line, right on that
pixel right there.
So we're down to pixel-level accuracy.
Now it could slide left or right.
I'm not sure where it's going to end up
yet, but at least the baseline is
established. Now I'm going to scale this
from the same midpoint and I'm going to
delete the original and use interactive
scaling. OK, and what I'm going to do is
pick that up here and zoom way in here
until I can see the actual pixels and I'm
going to place that down right there.
Ok, great.
It's interesting, when it's on the left
side, it kind of frames her face.
But let's take a look at some other
symbolism here, I'm going to turn on the
red layer and maybe I'll turn off the
orange and yellow layers so we can focus
in on this geometry.
In fact, what I'll do is go into the
golden rectangle block itself and I'd
like to see the same type of geometry on
the other side as well.
So I'm going to Shift-select these two
elements and then mirror them along this
line and I'm going to keep the original.
Ok, I'll go back to model space.
So that's the geometry that's needed to
construct the golden rectangle.
I'm just going to slide this over
horizontally a little bit here.
I'll select that and translate it.
I'll pick it up. I'll turn ortho mode on
and just slide it over horizontally until
those arcs line up with her hair.
So it's a very nice fit.
They're framing her head and then the
golden ratio division here separates her
head from the rest of her body.
And this "X" seems to point out her heart
on the left side. I'm also going to draw
a line right up the middle.
I'll go back into the golden rectangle
here and draw in a line on the red layer
from the middle here, all the way up to
that point. I'll go back into model space
and you can see that that goes right
through her eye. So I think we're getting
all kinds of confirmation here that this
was the basis of this particular
painting, and that's my theory that I've
written about in this book that I wrote
called, "Secrets in Plain Sight: Leonardo
da Vinci," that Leonardo consistently
laid out his artwork using the golden
rectangle. And then so basically, he
started with his science, what he
called,"a very secret science," the
science of the golden ratio.
He started with that and then he layered
his art on top of that.
And I believe that is why we hold up his
art as the most important art in the
world, but we don't necessarily
understand why.
I don't think very many people know how
his art is based on the golden rectangle,
but it's nevertheless something that we
can experience as something beautiful and
we don't even have to be aware of why.
We just know it's good.
And that's the kind of power that the
golden rectangle has.
Let's examine that again over here in
Michelangelo's work.
So I'm going to make a copy of this, I'll
use translate. Copy this over and of
course, we need to rotate this.
So I'll type RO for rotate and I'm going
to rotate it 90 degrees.
And then I'm just going to translate it
again, but not copy it this time.
What I'm going to do here is focus on the
the left edge here and in a place that's
right on the last pixel here.
I'm going to scale it from the middle.
I'll use interactive scaling.
I'm going to scale that all the way over
here so that the golden rectangle is
perfectly suited to the width of the
entire fresco. Now, whereas this golden
rectangle's golden ratio line right here,
whereas that it's right between the
fingers. So, that's no accident!
I think this is part of why we think it's
so beautiful. Let's take a look, though,
at some of the other secondary levels of
order that are going on here with the the
spiral. So I want to take this now and
translate it up.
I'll use ortho so it just slides straight
up. And what I'm going to do is to try to
line that up with his eye right there.
Now, basically, I think it's upside down.
So I'm going to flip this over by
mirroring it along this line right here.
And I'm going to delete the original.
There we go. So it's lined up with this
golden ratio line going right through his
eye and he's essentially looking straight
into the heart of God.
This curve of the spiral is very neatly
describing the shape of his body.
So, again, I think Michelangelo took a
cue from the older Leonardo in using this
"secret science" in structuring his work.
And so I think this is the kind of thing
that you can find out when you use Q to
analyze works of art - you can uncover
hidden geometric structure underlying
great art.
